title: Synthesis Skills for Early Career Researchers
text: As part of the 2025-29 renewal proposal to the National Science Foundation the Long Term Ecological Research (LTER) Network Office proposed an yearlong course to train early career researchers in synthesis work. Synthesis skills differ from primary research skills because synthesis requires a focus on collaboration as well as an increased emphasis on quantitative skills. Synthesis Skills for Early Career Researchers (SSECR) is that course and it will be first offered in fall of 2024 to a cohort of ~30 students (about 1 per LTER site). The course materials can be found at lter.github.io/ssecr though they will likely be under construction/revision until late 2024/early 2025.

title: LTER Synthesis Course

LTER Sites
 



27 sites in the network




a

title: LTER Synthesis Course
text:
Course Goals
 

Surface and test new synthesis ideas for feasibility
Prepare more graduate students to be effective participants in/leaders of the synthesis project
Connect LTER graduate students across sites
Develop intergenerational linkages around synthesis research

title: LTER Synthesis Course
text:
Course Structure
 

Participants: ~27 (approx. 1 graduate students from each LTER site)
Time frame: Biweekly meetings (1 session / 2 weeks) over the course of 9 months
Course management: LTER Network Office (LNO)
Instruction: LNO staff, guest speakers, LTER Network-recruited mentors

title: LTER Synthesis Course
text:
Module Categories
 


All 15 proposed modules fall under one of two categories




Team Science 

Team Science Practices
Inclusive Facilitation
Supporting Divergent, Emergent, and Convergent Thinking
Authorship & Intellectual Credit
Project Management
Logic Models
Communicating Findings


Quantitative Skills 

Reproducibility Best Practices
Version Control
Data Discovery & Management
Data Visualization and Exploration
Data Wrangling
Analysis & Modeling
Spatial Data & Interactivity
Reproducible Reports

title: LTER Presentations
text: This website (and the repository that supports it) are a convenient mechanism for (A) sharing LTER-associated presentations, (B) standardizing formatting conventions of those talks, and (C) incentivizing me to engage more deeply with Quarto presentations.
